voyage: Chapter 3: Comparing a Globe and a Map; Field Visits
lessons: Comparing a globe and a map

questions.question: Which of the following devices is flat in shape?
questions.answer: Map

questions.question: Which device represents the Earth in a spherical form?
questions.answer: Globe

questions.question: Which device allows you to see the entire Earth at the same time?
questions.answer: Map

questions.question: Which device allows you to see only one side of the Earth at a time?
questions.answer: Globe

questions.question: Which device is suitable for studying a particular region in detail?
questions.answer: Map

questions.question: Which device can be called a model of the Earth?
questions.answer: Globe

questions.question: A surface having only length and width is called
questions.answer: Two-dimensional

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a two-dimensional object?
questions.answer: Paper

questions.question: An object having length, width and height is called
questions.answer: Three-dimensional

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a three-dimensional object?
questions.answer: Globe

questions.question: What does the product of length and width define?
questions.answer: Area

questions.question: What does the product of length, width and height define?
questions.answer: Volume

questions.question: Maps are useful for studying

options.text: The whole world and limited regions

questions.answer: The whole world and limited regions

questions.question: Even if a globe is small or large, it represents
questions.answer: The entire Earth

questions.question: Which method is described as important for studying geography?
questions.answer: Field visit

questions.question: Field visits help students to understand
questions.answer: Geographical and social conditions

questions.question: What additional benefit do field visits provide?
questions.answer: Direct interaction with local people

questions.question: Which of the following places is suggested for a field visit?
questions.answer: Planetarium

questions.question: Before drawing a world map, what is first prepared?
questions.answer: Wire globe

questions.question: What is placed inside the wire globe during map preparation?
questions.answer: Source of light

questions.question: What is obtained on paper from the wire globe?
questions.answer: Projection of wire graticule

questions.question: What is essential for drawing a map of the Earth?
questions.answer: Graticule

questions.question: A two-dimensional map is obtained from
questions.answer: A three-dimensional globe

questions.question: Which globe is mentioned as the largest operational globe in the world?
questions.answer: EARTHA

questions.question: Where is the globe EARTHA located?
questions.answer: Yarmouth, Maine, USA

questions.question: The rotation and revolution speed of EARTHA is maintained as per
questions.answer: The Earth

questions.question: Which device is easier to carry from one place to another?
questions.answer: Map

questions.question: Which device is more suitable to show a village or city?
questions.answer: Map

questions.question: Which device is suitable to understand day and night on Earth?
questions.answer: Globe

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as a field visit location?
questions.answer: Airport

questions.question: Which activity is suggested during a field visit?
questions.answer: Preparing a questionnaire

questions.question: Which task is suggested after interviewing local people?
questions.answer: Note down responses

questions.question: Which figure shows the world map in the chapter?
questions.answer: Figure 3.1(a)

questions.question: Which figure shows the outline map of India?
questions.answer: Figure 3.1(b)

questions.question: Which figure shows a globe?
questions.answer: Figure 3.1(c)

questions.question: What should teachers facilitate for this lesson?
questions.answer: Globes and maps

questions.question: Which object is listed as an example of a three-dimensional object?
questions.answer: Duster

questions.question: Which object is listed as an example of a two-dimensional object?
questions.answer: Table top

questions.question: Which term is used for a network of parallels and meridians?
questions.answer: Graticule

questions.question: What is studied by observing places like bus stations and malls?
questions.answer: Geographical and social conditions

questions.question: Who guides students during a field visit?
questions.answer: Teacher

questions.question: Which action is suggested after a field visit?
questions.answer: Make sketches or notes

questions.question: Which statement correctly compares maps and globes?

options.text: Maps are two-dimensional and globes are three-dimensional

questions.answer: Maps are two-dimensional and globes are three-dimensional

questions.question: Which device helps to understand the true shape of the Earth?
questions.answer: Globe

questions.question: Which is easier to store in a bag?
questions.answer: Map

questions.question: Which device is more accurate in showing Earth’s shape?
questions.answer: Globe

questions.question: Which concept is easier to understand using a globe?
questions.answer: Day and night

questions.question: Which device shows distortion when representing the Earth?
questions.answer: Map

questions.question: Which item is specifically mentioned under Geography Museum?
questions.answer: EARTHA globe

questions.question: Which approach is encouraged in the chapter for learning geography?
questions.answer: Observation and direct study

questions.question: Why are meridians and parallels drawn on a globe?
questions.answer: Meridians and parallels are drawn on a globe to determine the location of places on the Earth.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of comparing a map and a globe?
questions.answer: The main purpose is to understand the differences between a map and a globe.

questions.question: What materials are suggested for group activity in this lesson?
questions.answer: A world map, a map of India and a globe are suggested for the group activity.

questions.question: Why is a map called a flat device?
questions.answer: A map is called a flat device because it has only length and width.

questions.question: Why is a globe described as spherical?
questions.answer: A globe is spherical because it represents the Earth in a round, ball-like form.

questions.question: Why can the entire Earth be seen at the same time on a map?
questions.answer: The entire Earth can be seen at the same time on a map because it is a flat representation.

questions.question: Why can only one side of the Earth be seen on a globe at a time?
questions.answer: Only one side can be seen on a globe at a time because it is spherical.

questions.question: Why is a map suitable for studying a particular region in detail?
questions.answer: A map is suitable because it can show small or large regions with detailed information.

questions.question: Why is a globe considered a model of the Earth?
questions.answer: A globe is considered a model because it represents the entire Earth in reduced form.

questions.question: What is meant by a two-dimensional surface?
questions.answer: A two-dimensional surface has only length and width.

questions.question: Give two examples of two-dimensional objects mentioned in the lesson.
questions.answer: Paper and blackboard are examples of two-dimensional objects.

questions.question: What is meant by a three-dimensional object?
questions.answer: A three-dimensional object has length, width and height.

questions.question: Give two examples of three-dimensional objects mentioned in the lesson.
questions.answer: A box and a globe are examples of three-dimensional objects.

questions.question: How is the area of a two-dimensional object calculated?
questions.answer: The area is calculated by multiplying length and width.

questions.question: How is the volume of a three-dimensional object calculated?
questions.answer: The volume is calculated by multiplying length, width and height.

questions.question: How can maps be used in geographical studies?
questions.answer: Maps can be used to study the whole world or regions of limited extent.

questions.question: Why is a globe limited in use compared to a map?
questions.answer: A globe represents the entire Earth and cannot show small regions in great detail.

questions.question: Why are field visits important in geography?
questions.answer: Field visits help in understanding geographical and social conditions of a place.

questions.question: What additional understanding do field visits provide to students?
questions.answer: They provide an opportunity to directly interact with local people and understand their problems.

questions.question: Name any two places suggested for a geography field visit.
questions.answer: A planetarium and a hill are suggested places for a geography field visit.

questions.question: Who guides students during a field visit?
questions.answer: Teachers guide students during a field visit.

questions.question: Why is a questionnaire prepared before a field visit?
questions.answer: A questionnaire is prepared to collect relevant information through interviews.

questions.question: What records are students expected to maintain during a field visit?
questions.answer: Students should note responses, make sketches and write notes.

questions.question: What is the first step in drawing a map of the whole world?
questions.answer: The first step is preparing a wire globe.

questions.question: Why is a source of light placed inside the wire globe?
questions.answer: A source of light is placed to obtain the projection of the wire graticule on paper.

questions.question: What is meant by a graticule?
questions.answer: A graticule is a network of parallels and meridians.

questions.question: Why is a graticule essential for drawing maps?
questions.answer: A graticule helps in accurately drawing the Earth or its parts on a map.

questions.question: How is a two-dimensional map obtained from a globe?
questions.answer: A two-dimensional map is obtained by projecting the wire graticule of a globe onto paper.

questions.question: Why should objects be classified based on dimensions?
questions.answer: Classification helps in understanding their structure and proper use.

questions.question: When should a globe be used instead of a map?
questions.answer: A globe should be used when understanding the shape of the Earth or day and night.

questions.question: When is a map preferred over a globe?
questions.answer: A map is preferred when studying a specific region in detail.

questions.question: Why is a map easier to carry than a globe?
questions.answer: A map is flat and lightweight, making it easier to carry.

questions.question: Why is a globe not convenient for daily use?
questions.answer: A globe is bulky and shows only one side of the Earth at a time.

questions.question: Which device helps in understanding day and night on Earth?
questions.answer: A globe helps in understanding the concept of day and night.

questions.question: Which device is suitable to show a village or city?
questions.answer: A map is suitable to show a village or city.

questions.question: Why is observation important in geographical studies?
questions.answer: Observation helps in understanding real geographical conditions directly.

questions.question: What learning approach is emphasized in this chapter?
questions.answer: The chapter emphasizes learning through observation and practical study.

questions.question: What is EARTHA?
questions.answer: EARTHA is the largest operational globe in the world.

questions.question: Where is the globe EARTHA housed?
questions.answer: EARTHA is housed at Yarmouth in the State of Maine in the United States of America.

questions.question: What is special about the movement of the EARTHA globe?
questions.answer: Its rotation and revolution speed are maintained as per that of the Earth.

questions.question: Why is EARTHA important for geographical learning?
questions.answer: EARTHA accurately represents the Earth’s rotation and revolution.

questions.question: What does a field visit help students observe?
questions.answer: A field visit helps students observe geographical features and social conditions.

questions.question: Why should students interact with local people during field visits?
questions.answer: Interaction helps students understand local problems and conditions.

questions.question: What skills are developed through field visits?
questions.answer: Observation, interaction and recording skills are developed through field visits.

questions.question: Why are sketches useful during a field visit?
questions.answer: Sketches help in visually recording observed features.

questions.question: How does map projection help in geography?
questions.answer: Map projection helps in representing the Earth’s surface on a flat paper.

questions.question: Why is a globe more accurate than a map?
questions.answer: A globe shows the true shape of the Earth without distortion.

questions.question: Why does a map show distortion?
questions.answer: A map shows distortion because the curved surface of the Earth is shown on a flat surface.

questions.question: Why is classification of objects by dimensions useful?
questions.answer: It helps in selecting the correct object for specific geographical studies.

questions.question: What is the main learning outcome of this chapter?
questions.answer: The chapter helps in understanding the differences, uses and importance of maps, globes and field visits.

questions.question: Why are meridians and parallels important on a globe?
questions.answer: Meridians and parallels are important because they help determine the location of places on the Earth.

questions.question: Why is a globe not suitable for studying small areas in detail?
questions.answer: A globe represents the entire Earth and cannot show small areas with detailed information.

questions.question: Why is a map preferred for studying limited regions?
questions.answer: A map is preferred because it can show limited regions with greater detail.

questions.question: What limitation of a globe is highlighted in the lesson?
questions.answer: The lesson highlights that a globe shows only one side of the Earth at a time.

questions.question: Why is a globe considered only a representative model?
questions.answer: A globe is considered a representative model because it is a reduced version of the Earth.

questions.question: What does the term two-dimensional emphasize about an object?
questions.answer: The term two-dimensional emphasizes that the object has only length and width.

questions.question: Why is area associated only with two-dimensional objects?
questions.answer: Area is associated with two-dimensional objects because it is calculated using length and width.

questions.question: Why is volume associated with three-dimensional objects?
questions.answer: Volume is associated with three-dimensional objects because it depends on length, width and height.

questions.question: How does understanding dimensions help in geography?
questions.answer: Understanding dimensions helps in choosing appropriate tools like maps or globes for geographical study.

questions.question: Why is direct observation important in geography?
questions.answer: Direct observation helps in understanding real geographical and social conditions accurately.

questions.question: What role does interaction with local people play during field visits?
questions.answer: Interaction with local people helps understand their problems and local conditions.

questions.question: Why should interviews be conducted during field visits?
questions.answer: Interviews help collect firsthand information about the place being studied.

questions.question: Why should responses be noted during field visits?
questions.answer: Responses should be noted to accurately record information for later study.

questions.question: Why are sketches useful in geographical studies?
questions.answer: Sketches help visually represent and remember observed geographical features.

questions.question: Why is teacher guidance essential during a field visit?
questions.answer: Teacher guidance ensures proper observation, data collection and understanding.

questions.question: What geographical understanding is gained by visiting a planetarium?
questions.answer: A planetarium helps understand Earth and celestial representations related to geography.

questions.question: Why is a wire globe used before drawing a world map?
questions.answer: A wire globe is used to obtain the correct projection of the Earth’s graticule.

questions.question: How does light help in map preparation from a globe?
questions.answer: Light helps project the wire graticule of the globe onto paper.

questions.question: Why is the graticule necessary in map drawing?
questions.answer: The graticule ensures accurate representation of the Earth on a map.

questions.question: How does a globe help understand Earth’s shape better than a map?
questions.answer: A globe shows the Earth’s true spherical shape without distortion.

questions.question: Why does distortion occur on maps?
questions.answer: Distortion occurs because a curved surface of the Earth is shown on a flat map.

questions.question: Why is portability an advantage of maps?
questions.answer: Maps are lightweight and flat, making them easy to carry.

questions.question: Why is a globe difficult to transport?
questions.answer: A globe is bulky and three-dimensional, making it difficult to transport.

questions.question: Which device is more practical for classroom use and why?
questions.answer: Maps are more practical because they are easy to handle and store.

questions.question: Why is understanding day and night easier on a globe?
questions.answer: A globe helps visualize Earth’s rotation, making day and night easier to understand.

questions.question: Why is the globe considered accurate despite its small size?
questions.answer: The globe accurately represents the Earth’s shape and features in reduced form.

questions.question: What makes EARTHA different from ordinary globes?
questions.answer: EARTHA has rotation and revolution speeds maintained as per the Earth.

questions.question: Why is EARTHA useful for educational purposes?
questions.answer: EARTHA provides a realistic representation of Earth’s movements.

questions.question: Why is geography linked with social conditions in field visits?
questions.answer: Geography studies places along with the people living there and their conditions.

questions.question: Why should geographical studies not rely only on textbooks?
questions.answer: Geographical studies require observation and field experience beyond textbooks.

questions.question: How do maps and globes complement each other in geography?
questions.answer: Maps provide detail while globes provide accurate shape, together enhancing understanding.

questions.question: Why should students classify objects based on dimensions?
questions.answer: Classification helps in understanding their structure and correct application.

questions.question: What learning skill is strengthened through field visits?
questions.answer: Observation and analytical skills are strengthened through field visits.

questions.question: Why is preparation necessary before a field visit?
questions.answer: Preparation ensures systematic observation and data collection.

questions.question: How does studying a bus station help in geography?
questions.answer: It helps understand transport systems and human activities.

questions.question: Why are malls included as field visit locations?
questions.answer: Malls help study economic and social activities of a region.

questions.question: Why is a hill suggested as a field visit location?
questions.answer: A hill helps study natural landforms and geographical features.

questions.question: How does fieldwork support theoretical learning?
questions.answer: Fieldwork provides practical examples that support theoretical concepts.

questions.question: Why is accurate representation important in geography?
questions.answer: Accurate representation helps in correct understanding of Earth’s features.

questions.question: Why is a globe less commonly used than a map?
questions.answer: A globe is bulky and less convenient compared to a map.

questions.question: What does the lesson suggest about selecting geographical tools?
questions.answer: The lesson suggests selecting maps or globes based on the study requirement.

questions.question: Why is practical geography emphasized in the chapter?
questions.answer: Practical geography helps understand real-world geographical conditions.

questions.question: How does observation improve geographical understanding?
questions.answer: Observation allows direct study of features and conditions.

questions.question: Why should geography students maintain notes during activities?
questions.answer: Notes help in accurate recording and revision of observations.

questions.question: What educational value does the Geography Museum provide?
questions.answer: It provides visual and practical understanding of geographical concepts.

questions.question: Why is Eartha highlighted in the lesson?
questions.answer: Eartha is highlighted as the largest operational globe with realistic motion.

questions.question: How does field study help understand human-environment interaction?
questions.answer: It shows how people live and interact with their surroundings.

questions.question: Why is geography considered an observational subject?
questions.answer: Geography requires observing Earth’s features and human activities.

questions.question: What attitude towards learning geography is promoted in this chapter?
questions.answer: An attitude of observation, inquiry and practical learning is promoted.

questions.question: What is the overall importance of maps, globes and field visits in geography?
questions.answer: They collectively help in accurate, practical and comprehensive understanding of geography.
